Executive Summary



This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for Global Petroleum 

Corporation?s (Global) Revere, Massachusetts bulk petroleum terminal.  This Plan has 

been developed in accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Part 

68, ?Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions?.  The purpose of these provisions and 

this RMP is to prevent accidental releases of toxic and flammable substances that can 

cause harm to the public and to the environment.



This RMP was originally developed by Triton Environmental, Inc. on behalf of Global 

specifically to prevent and mitigate accidental releases associated with butane storage 

(temporary storage) and handling operations at the Revere facility.  The RMP provides 

a summary of the risk management program implemented at the Terminal and was 

developed following the Environmental Protection Agency?s ?Risk Management 

Program Guidance for Propane Storage Facilities (40 CFR 68)?.  The RMP is available 

to government agencies and the public for review.



Tighe & Bond has performed the requisite review and regulatory update necessary for 

covered facilities on their five year RMP Submission Anniversary.  This review 

included:



*    A hazard analysis of the covered process using a methodology involving 

checklists developed from EPA RMP Guidance and NFPA 58, as well as a 

physical inspection of the covered process;

*    

*    Performance of an off site consequence analysis (OCA) taking into account data 

revised from the year 2000 census; and

*    

*    A general review of operating and maintenance procedures with facility 

operations and environmental personnel.

*    

This Plan has been designed to serve as a ?stand alone? document, as well as, to be 

part of the Terminal?s Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP).



The following items provide and overview of Global?s RMP, in accordance with 40 

CFR 68.155.



Facility Description and Covered Process



Global operates a marine petroleum te

rminal at 140 Lee Burbank Highway in Revere, 

Massachusetts.  Activities at this terminal primarily include the storage and distribution 

of petroleum based fuel.  The terminal can be segregated into three operating areas; 

vessel dock, tank farm and loading rack.



The various products are off-loaded from marine vessels at the dock.  This dock is 

provided with cranes to maneuver transfer hoses, mooring line connections and 

breasting dolphins.  The docks have the necessary gauges to monitor transfer operation 

and drip pans to capture small spills.  Each dock is provided with a dock house to 

protect employees from the elements during dock operations.



Products may also be transferred to bulk storage tanks via a truck pump-off station.  A 

number of smaller additive and dye tanks at the terminal are filled directly from tanker 

trucks.



Distribution piping is used to transfer the product off-loaded from marine vessels to 

above ground storage tanks located in a segregated tank farm area.  Materials are 

transferred to the tank farm using pumps supplied on the transporting vessel.  Dock 

piping and the majority of piping in the tank farm areas are located above ground.



Products are transferred for sale to a truck loading rack or shoreline pumping station.  

This terminal also has the capability of transferring product to other terminals via intra-

facility piping.  Pumping to these locations is performed by inter-facility pumps through 

predominantly above ground piping.



The covered process at the terminal involves blending butane with gasoline in a 

controlled enclosed system.  Butane blending occurs in a designated area of the facility 

near the terminal office building.  The system incorporates a 100 gallon storage tank, 

loading towers, an indirect bath vaporizer, blending system and associated piping 

systems.



Butane stock is temporarily stored at the facility in two rail cars with a maximum 

capacity of 144,738 pounds per rai

l car.  Global maintains the rail siding next to the 

butane blending area.  Butane rail cars are transferred to the siding by designated 

contractors.



The rail cars are connected to the blend system by Global employees.  Butane blending 

is performed during gasoline transfers from ships or barges (when necessary).  The 

area is continuously monitored by trained Global employees at all times during blending 

operations.  The 100 gallon permanent storage tank is used to maintain proper pressure 

balance in the rail cars, necessary for consistent butane delivery to the blend system.



Since the original RMP submission, Global has temporarily stopped operating the 

covered process.  The system was shut down, purged with nitrogen and all unloading 

connections were capped in September 2001.  However, butane blending operations 

may commence at any time in the future, which necessitates this program and 

predictive filing.



In the event that this process operation was to continue, a detailed engineering review 

and maintenance inspection of the covered process would be performed prior to starting 

blending operations.  Corrective actions, as a result of the engineering review and the 

Process Hazard Analysis conducted on June 8, 2004, would be addressed prior to 

startup of the system.

Regulated Substance: Butane



Release Scenarios



A worst case release scenario and two alternative release scenarios were performed and 

documented in the original RMP filing.  These scenarios were recalculated for the five 

year anniversary updating population and receptor information.



Based on guidelines provided by EPA in the 2004 RMP Submit Instruction Manual, 

release scenario information is not provided in this Executive Summary.



Administrative and Enginee

ring Controls



Global has implemented a prevention program (RMP Program 2) to administratively 

limit the potential for a worst case or alternative release.  No passive measures, 

however, were taken to minimize the impacts of these releases.  Specific measures 

employed in this program include safety reviews, hazard reviews, operating procedure 

reviews, training and maintenance and inspection.  These reviews are conducted, 

consistent with the operation of the covered process, once (1) every three (3) years in 

association with Global?s Compliance Audit (40 CFR 68.58) or with major changes.  

The hazard review is required every five (5) years or with major changes.  Maintenance 

and inspection is conducted annually when the system is in operation.  These 

procedures are outlined in Global?s RMP maintained at the facility.  The results of the 

most recent reviews are also maintained at the facility.



Since the covered process has not been in operation since at least September 2001, 

regular maintenance of the system is not required.  However, the area is inspected 

periodically to identify any significant deterioration of the system.  Prior to restart of 

the covered process, a detailed engineering analysis will be conducted and relevant 

corrective actions will be implemented.



Mitigation Measures



Certain engineering controls are used to mitigate the potential effects of the alternative 

release scenarios.  Such measures include check valves, excess flow valves and 

emergency shut-off valves.



General Accidental Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention 

Items



Global has implemented a Program 2 RMP to prevent the release of flammable 

substances that can cause harm to the public and the environment.  Program 2, in 

general, consists of the following:



*    Safety Information (Sect. 68.48)

*    

*    Hazard Review (Sect. 68.50)

*    

*    Operating Procedures (Sect. 68.52)

*    

*    Training (Sect. 68.54)

*    

*    Maintenance (Sect. 68.

56)

*    

*    Compliance Audits (Sect. 68.58)

*    

*    Incident Investigation (Sect. 68.60)

*    

*    Emergency Response Program (Sect. 68.90)

*    

This Program 2 RMP has been implemented at the facility and Global maintains a copy 

available for review on-site.



Five Year Accident History



There have been no releases of butane at Global in the five (5) years preceding the 

submission of this RMP.



Emergency Response Program



Global has initiated its Emergency Response Program with local agencies.  The Fire 

Department and Police Department maintain copies of the facility Emergency Plan.  

Appropriate contacts are also in place with emergency response contractors, if 

necessary.



Global has developed strong working relationships with local emergency response 

organizations.  In addition, Global has developed an Emergency Plan, which provides 

guidance for progressively managing emergency episodes, such as spills, fires, 

explosions and other sudden/unplanned events.  In accordance with 40 CFR 68.90 

(b)(2) and (b)(3), Global has coordinated response actions associated with butane 

storage (temporary storage) and handling with the local fire department.  The facility?s 

Integrated Contingency Plan and Emergency Plan provide guidance mechanisms for 

notification of emergency responders.  Copies of the Emergency Plan are maintained at 

the facility for use in an emergency incident, and have been forwarded to the local Fire 

Department, the local Police Department and area hospitals.  As such, development of 

a new and separate emergency response program is not required in accordance with 40 

CFR 68.95 since an emergency response program already exists.



Safety Improvements



The following list provides a summary of items implemented at Global in association 

with this Plan that are designed to improve safety.



*    Safety Review (Audit every 3 years)

*    

*    Hazard Review (Audit every 3 years, update every 5 years)

*    

*    Operating Procedures Review

(Audit every 3 years)

*    

*    Training (Audit every 3 years, training once every 3 years (minimum))

*    

*    Maintenance and Inspection (conducted annually, audit every 3 years)

*    

*    Emergency Response Program (coordination with local agencies (fire 

department), development of an Emergency Plan)

*    

A Process Hazard Analysis update was conducted on June 8, 2004 and involved 

operations, management and environmental personnel.  The updated analysis identified 

some minor recommendations that must be implemented by Global prior to restart of 

the covered process.  Copies of the Process Hazard Analysis report are maintained at 

the Revere terminal.
